Article.Abstract: During viral infection, constitutive proteasomes are largely replaced by immunoproteasomes, which display distinct cleavage specificities, resulting in different populations of potential CD8(+) T cell epitope peptides. Immunoproteasomes are believed to be important for the generation of many viral CD8(+) T cell epitopes and have been implicated in shaping the immunodominance hierarchies of CD8(+) T cell responses to influenza virus infection. However, it remains unclear whether these conclusions are generally applicable. In this study we investigated the CD8(+) T cell responses to lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus infection and DNA immunization in wild-type mice and in mice lacking the immunoproteasome subunits LMP2 or LMP7. Although the total number of virus-specific cells was lower in LMP2 knockout mice, consistent with their having lower numbers of naive cells before infection, the kinetics of virus clearance were similar in all three mouse strains, and LMP-deficient mice mounted strong primary and secondary lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus-specific CD8(+) T cell responses. Furthermore, the immunodominance hierarchy of the four investigated epitopes (nuclear protein 396 (NP(396)) > gp33 > gp276 > NP(205)) was well maintained. We observed a slight reduction in the NP(205)-specific response in LMP2-deficient mice, but this had no demonstrable biological consequence. DNA vaccination of LMP2- and LMP7-deficient mice induced CD8(+) T cell responses that were slightly lower than, although not significantly different from, those induced in wild-type mice. Taken together, our results challenge the notion that immunoproteasomes are generally needed for effective antiviral CD8(+) T cell responses and for the shaping of immunodominance hierarchies. We conclude that the immunoproteasome may affect T cell responses to only a limited number of viral epitopes, and we propose that its main biological function may lie elsewhere.
Article.ArticleTitle: Immunoproteasome-deficient mice mount largely normal CD8+ T cell responses to lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus infection and DNA vaccination.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Neuropharmacology, The Scripps Research Institute, 10550 North Torrey Pines Road, La Jolla, CA 92037, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Histocompatibility Antigens Class I;Immunodominant Epitopes;Multienzyme Complexes;Nucleoproteins;Peptide Fragments;Vaccines, DNA;LMP-2 protein;Cysteine Endopeptidases;LMP7 protein;Proteasome Endopeptidase Complex
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; CD8-Positive T-Lymphocytes(enzymology; immunology; virology); Cysteine Endopeptidases(deficiency; genetics; physiology); Dose-Response Relationship, Immunologic; Histocompatibility Antigens Class I(biosynthesis); Immunodominant Epitopes(administration & dosage; biosynthesis; immunology); Lymphocyte Count; Lymphocytic Choriomeningitis(enzymology; genetics; immunology; virology); Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus(immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Mice, Knockout; Molecular Sequence Data; Multienzyme Complexes(deficiency; genetics; physiology); Nucleoproteins(administration & dosage; immunology); Peptide Fragments(administration & dosage; immunology); Proteasome Endopeptidase Complex; T-Lymphocyte Subsets(cytology; enzymology; virology); Vaccines, DNA(administration & dosage; immunology); Viral Load

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Primary infection with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU, secondary infection with 2x10<sup>6</sup> PFU.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 8 days after 1ary or 4 days after secondary infections, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The percentage of epitope specific T cells is identical in wild type and immunoproteasome deficient (LPM2 or LMP7 knockout) mice, even though the total lymphocyte population is lower in LPM2 knockout mice. Similar results are seen in the memory response after secondary infection, but are lower, although not statistically significantly lower in response to this epitope in LPM2 knockout mice. These results are in correlation with the intact capacity of knockout mice to effectively clear LCMV infections. Other epitopes analyzed are also similar in their responses to the different genotypes, showing that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are not responsible for setting the CD8+ immunodominance hierarchy during primary or secondary LCMV infection.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 3 weeks after last immunization, mice were innoculated with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU LCMV and 4 days later, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The percentage of epitope specific T cells after 1, 2, and 3 DNA vaccinations with plasmid encoding source protein is not statistically different in wild type and immunoproteasome deficient (LPM2 or LMP7 knockout) mice. Responses against the epitope 4 days after challenge with the source species are also not statistically different between wild type and knockout mice Other immunodominant epitopes analyzed also give similar responses to the different genotypes, showing that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are dispensable for the generation of epitopes from DNA vaccines.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Primary infection with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU, secondary infection with 2x10<sup>6</sup> PFU.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 8 days after 1ary or 4 days after secondary infections, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The number of epitope specific T cells is similar in wild type and immunoproteasome deficient (LMP7 knockout) mice and lower (~10-fold) in MP2 knockout mice in which the total lymphocyte population is also lower. The biological relevance of this reduced response is doutful because LMP2 KO mice have an intact capacity to effectively clear LCMV infections. No differences are seen among the different genotypes in the memory response after secondary infection. Other epitopes analyzed are also similar in their responses in the different genotypes, showing that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are not responsible for setting the CD8+ immunodominance hierarchy during primary or secondary LCMV infection.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 3 weeks after last immunization, mice were innoculated with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU LCMV and 4 days later, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: After 3 DNA vaccinations with plasmid encoding source protein, mice were challenged with the source species. 4 days later, specific T cells against this subdominant epitope are not detectable in either wild type or immunoproteasome deficient (LPM2 or LMP7 knockout) mice. With the immunodominant epitopes, a similarly strong response is seen in the different genotypes, demonstrating that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are dispensable for the generation of epitopes from DNA vaccines.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 2 vaccinations 3 wks apart, with 50 micrograms epitopic peptide and 47 micrograms of each of the Th epitopes.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Animals were immunized with an emulsion of the epitope along with Th epitopes from HBV (TPPAYRPPNADPIL), lambda repressor 12 (YLEDARRLKAIYEKKK) and OVA323 (ISQAVHAAHAEINE). 14 days after last immunization, PBMCs were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The reduced response to this epitope in LMP2 knockout mice infected with virus was not due to a lower MHC I Kb expression on lymphocytes nor to a lower ability of T cells to mount a response. A similar response was seen in wildtype and knockout mice after peptide immunization. This raises the possibility that proteasomes in LMP2 knockout mice may be marginally less effective in generating this epitope from source protein.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Primary infection with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU, secondary infection with 2x10<sup>6</sup> PFU.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 8 days after 1ary or 4 days after secondary infections, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The percentages of epitope specific T cells is similar in wildtype and immunoproteasome deficient (LMP7 knockout) mice and is not significantly lower in LMP2 knockout mice, correlating with the intact capacity of knockout mice to effectively clear LCMV infections. Similar results are seen in the memory response after secondary infection, but with a change in the immunodominance pattern in favor of another epitope from the source protein, both in wildtype and knockout mice. Other epitopes analyzed are also similar in their responses to the different genotypes, demonstrating that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are not responsible for setting the CD8+ immunodominance hierarchy during primary or secondary LCMV infection.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 3 weeks after last immunization, mice were innoculated with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU LCMV and 4 days later, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The numbers of epitope specific T cells are not statistically different between the different genotypes at 4 days after challenge demonstrating that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are dispensable for the generation of epitopes from DNA vaccines.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Primary infection with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU, secondary infection with 2x10<sup>6</sup> PFU.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 8 days after 1ary or 4 days after secondary infections, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope specific T cells are similar in wild type and immunoproteasome deficient (LMP7 knockout) mice and are not significantly lower in LMP2 KO mice, correlating with the intact capacity of knockout mice to effectively clear LCMV infections. Similar results are seen in the memory response after secondary infection, but with a change in the immunodominance pattern favoring a stronger response against this epitope than to the immunodominant epitope GP33 of the source protein, both in wild type and knockout mice. Other epitopes analyzed are also similar in their responses in the different genotypes, showing that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are not responsible for setting the CD8+ immunodominance hierarchy during primary or secondary LCMV infection.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: 3 weeks after last immunization, mice were innoculated with 2x10<sup>5</sup> PFU LCMV and 4 days later, spleen cells were harvested, incubated 5-7 hs with peptide, and analyzed for cytokine staining. No information on the plasmid vector is provided.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope specific T cells are not present 4 days after challenge with the source species in DNA vaccinated wild type or immunoproteasome deficient (LPM2 knockout) mice, while in LMP7 mice they are detectable, although not to the level in source species immunized mice. These findings are consistent with an altered immunodominance hierarchy with the use of DNA vaccination. Similar results among the different genotypes are also seen for other epitopes, showing that the immunoproteasome proteins LPM2 and 7 are dispensable for the generation of epitopes from DNA vaccines.
